Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

Anorexia is more immediately dangerous than obesity, putting on or dropping 5% of your body weight is nothing if you’re 150lbs but if you’re 80lbs then losing that 5% could be lethal. Meanwhile, obeastoids can reach 600lbs or more and still be alive, though it obviously won’t be for much longer. This coupled with the body image self esteem push back in the 00s in response to 90s’ glorification of near-anorexic women’s’ bodies made anything to do with anorexia a very sensitive issue. However, the fat acceptance movement catching on more and more around the same time provided the perfect opportunity for deluded lards and other "special interest groups" (the fast food and medical industries) to push for fat acceptance. If thin bad, then fat good??? Utterly ridiculous line of thinking but that kind of reactionary shit is very appealing to people who feel marginalised, be it genuine or not, so we now have a society where morbid obesity is accepted and praised while anorexia is demonised. Both are terrible and will kill you, one just kills quicker than the other while the other is easy to make money off, so corporations, grifters, and genuine retards all did what they do best and here we are. Everything was just timed very conveniently, it probably wouldn’t have caught on even just a decade earlier.

>>69919632
mechanical tension is the only driver of muscle growth

no it isn't, your muscles don't record how many sets you do, your muscle fibers are either exposed to enough tension or they're not, there's no myofibrillar logbook

volume is far more correlated with muscle damage than hypertrophy

this explains why people have trained very differently for decades and achieved amazing physiques, muscles don't know how to count how many reps or sets you're doing they only experience tension
stop with the high volume shit already

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69927922
You're super shaky. Too much caffeine?
Form is fine but as the weight goes up you will wanna begin learning the lift in various stages rather than just kinda panicking and yeeting it up.
>Slightly wide conventional stance pick
>'Lap' the weight and bring your chest to the log
>Rotate arms so elbows are out
>Explode up while keeping log in contact with chest
>Roll/wedge arms up under the log, forearms vertical
>Hip/Leg drive by bending knees outward, not forward
>Explode up with drive + press

Notes:
>Keep elbows high when in front rack position or the log will roll down your body and you lose a good position
>It's tempting to keep arms in neutral grip for the roll but this can tear biceps fast af and is weaker overall
>Core braced the whole damn time and when you're in the front rack position CLENCH YOUR GLUTES to keep rigidly upright
>Knees outward on the drive because going forward will risk balance and doesn't transfer as well, also might make torso lean forward and lose the log

Good luck anon. I'm not perfect at em but I dabbled with em at a gym in OKC that had a Rogue log for a couple weeks and hit 235.

If I had more frequent/full-time access to the log I'd do:

>Full range comp style reps
>Log deadlifts with heavier weight than comp
>Incline Bench or Standing OHP with the log out of rack
>Log Cleans

All in an effort to build up the main comp movement. This might be a dumb take but, I'm sure the 2 strongman guys here will have input.

>>69928085
So, the grip of your hand is of course neutral but you can adjust your arm position relative to the floor/the log to adjust how you get it up. Youtube is your best friend here, Brian Alsruhe has a video guide or two.
Best text I can offer is to imagine you lay flat on a bench and do close grip reps with the log, but instead of coming down so your forearm stays vertical you come down by just drifting your elbows out. Now apply the way it'd look at the bottom of that CG press, to the way you hold it out of your lap from the bottom.

Pull
> Pull-ups
> Diddlies
> Row exercise, prefer cables to spare lowerback
> Facepulls
> Hammer curls
> Bicep curl
> (SHRUGS)

Push
> Bench
> Incline Bench
> (I'd add cable flies cause i want bigger tits)
> OHP (can do OHP first every other workout instead of bench)
> Any lateral raise
> Skullcrushers or overhead triceps exercise
> Tricep extensions pushdowns thing
> (SHRUGS)

Legs
> Main squat compound exercise
> RDLs or any diddly accessory, posterior chain
> Bulgarian split squats
> Calf raise of your choice I do seated atm
> Hyperextentions for gloots
> Leg raises
> Cable crunches

These movements should cover most of the muscles. Just pick whatever exercise variation you enjoy, dumbell benching or cable/dumbell rowing up to you. Pull/Push/Legs/x REPAT is imo the superior scheduling to rest lower back between diddlies and squat but take a rest day whenever you need it. Throw in shrugs if you want bigger traps wherever you feel like.

>>69923932
The cheapest leg press I'd even is the titan vertical leg press for $500. a cheap squat rack is $200-300, and a decent barbell is about $200. Obviously either way you're going to need to buy plates. If you spring for quality, a good linear leg press like the one in your pic is easily 2k-6k, while getting a top of the line squat rack and barbell is going to be at the most, 2k-3.
With a leg press you can do: leg press, single leg press, and calf press. With a barbell and squat rack you can do squats, deadlifts, calf raises, OHP, pull ups...
Not to mention squat racks have a crazy amount of attachments. If you add a pulley attachment, you have access to probably 80-90% of traditional weighted exercises.
Advising anyone to buy a leg press before a squat rack is ridiculous.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69931859
M/W/F; A/B/A, B/A/B, repeat.

A1: pullups, band assisted 3 - 4 x 6 - 12 reps, OR negatives. Gradually accumulate negatives per workout, then per week until you can do pullups.
A2: dumbbell OHP 3 - 4 x 6 - 12.
A3: Goblet squat 3 -4 x 6 - 12.
A4: curls, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.
A5: tricep extensions, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.

B1: dumbbell rows, same sets and reps.
B2: dumbbell bench, " "
B3: dumbbell RDL, " "
B4: curls, tricep ext, lateral raises super set; 3 sets per exercise, 8 - 12 reps.

2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69923444
What you describe are effects of anorexia and malnutrition. A caloric intake is 1k is quite low, but what matters quite significantly is that if you go that low you keep a close eye on your micros.
If you're a (wo)manlet that has a sub-2000 TDEE it might be necessary, but I don't think the average person ought to get that low, as long as you're okay losing 1-2lb per week. A 1000kcal deficit should be okay if you are obese, and means you lose a kilo a week on average.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69921256
I don't know how you could have approached me on this without me sending you to eat shit. If it doesn't start as their idea I don't love the odds. I think it's a huge waste of time to talk about health benefits to young people, if they haven't always been fat you can try an angle about how people treat you better when you're not that fat. Let's say they can be convinced to start on their weight loss journey, we have the issue of you wanting to work with them. I wouldn't have expected any great insight on this topic from someone just because he wasn't fat. If they let you in understand there are a lot of ways to lose weight, I mean it's likely they want control so if they want to choose the number of meals or at what time they want to have them or go a bit slower at the start they're the ones in charge and you being autistic about what the most efficient way to do it is is just going to make them reject you. There's also shit that's awful for them but it's likely they don't want to give up, like alcohol so you have to know what you're dealing with. You also need to deal with the problem that it's easier to not think about eating when you're not talking about eating, so if you want to do some followup on how their diets are going they may get irritable because that question itself makes them hungry. They're also going to do a little cheat here and there they don't want to tell you about. If you see any physical progress don't make a big deal about it but it's something they may want to hear as long as it's sincere. Goals can be a positive thing, but every time I failed one it made me want to give up on the whole thing and checking the cronometer chart on weight over some amount of time can be enough to make them realize they're achieving something.

There's another path I'm thinking about now which is making some kind of bet, if the bet's against a third person and you're putting down your money it makes it more natural to be involved in the journey.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69928916
long, complex, arduous tasks are best broken down into short, simple, nearly effortless ones. If you're a fat lazy alcoholic retard and you decide to quit drinking cold turkey, start a 1000kcal deficit low carb diet, join a powerlifting gym and enroll into a phd program, you won't last a day. If, on the other hand, you start by getting the normal beer instead of the extra-strength one, you put erythritol and milk in your morning coffee instead of sugar and cream, you do 2 sets of push ups and 2 sets of body squats when you wake up and you walk around the block in the evening, and you read 5 pages of a book you're interested in before going to sleep, it won't feel like much. It might even feel like it's not enough and you could do more. This is important: don't. The goal is to set a new baseline for yourself. Once these things just happen as a matter of course, not because you're willing yourself to do them but because that's just what you do now, increase the difficulty of each task. Are you familiar with the fable of the tortoise and the hare? The hare loses and regains the same 80 pounds every year and the tortoise loses 30 pounds a year.

Another thing: when you make healthy decisions make sure they're not decisions you can renege later. To bring back the example of the drunk, if you have 12 beers every night and you wanna cut it back to 6, you don't buy 12 beers and tell yourself you're gonna drink the other 6 the next day, you buy 6 beers close to closing time so you don't get the urge to go back. Similarly, "I'll only have 3 cookies out of this whole box" is a fool's promise. Have no cookies and mix some protein powder in greek yogurt instead

In the US, you have what is called "a reasonable expectation of privacy" in your own home or on your own property. Business owners have an expectation of privacy in their own business if they ban recording and can extend it to their customers by banning recording. I'm not a legal expert so don't quote me, but I think it's a misdemeanor to record someone when they have "a reasonable expectation of privacy" aka, on their own property.
Even if it isn't a misdemanor, once you ban someone from your property for breaking your businesses rules, if they show up again it's trespassing, which is a crime.

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.sub: The final solution to poverty benches
posts.com:
Stats:
330 lbs bench press @190 lbs bodyweight.
PT, specializing in fixing poverty benches
Has worked with josh bryant, THE best bench coach out there


>why is my bench so weak?
Lots of reasons, including: Weak rotator cuffs, weak scapular stability, weak prime movers because of weak rotator cuffs (chest activation inhibition), lack of tightness during bench.
I deeply believe that bench weakness has root in stabilizer weakness.


>what should i do?
Do all your benching paused, you have to learn to stay tight in the bottom.
Start training rotator cuffs and lower trap. Focus on getting these as strong as possible. Charles poliquin says 10% of bench press for 8 reps on db seated external rotation for structural stability.
You can use my sample bench program, which has it all covered.

>Exercises for lower traps, best to worst
t3 raise
iyt raise
Sternum pull up
Behind the neck press

>Rotator cuff
DB external rotation (infraspinatus)
lying side lateral raises (supraspinatus

also band pullaparts are great

Even by just starting to train your stabilizers, without running my sample program, you can expect to add a significant amount to your bench. Charles had someone add 50 lbs to their bench without training it just by doing these exercises (granted they had weak rotator cuffs to start)

Also antiperspirant causes gyno

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.com:
Here is probably my favorite bench press program- This has all bases covered, and is focused both on strength and hypertrophy. Expect large increases in bench. The bench frequency is a bit on the lower side, which will keep you fresh.
It is also a very fun program, most days are realatively short, and you will leave the gym with a big pump. It has a very large volume of upper back work, which lays the base for benching big weights.
A timer is mandatory, and you need to follow the rest periods exactly.
Also you have to fit stuff like pullups and dips to your own strength level, this is just a sample program

Day 1: Primary bench day (Upper body)
>6x5 Paused bench press, ~70% of max (will be very easy starting off, This is where you build technique maintaining tightness is key, try to pull the bar apart)
dont spend too long between sets (120-180 secs is enough, after you have done the seal rows). progress by adding 2 sets each week until you hit 10x5. then start decreasing sets and increasing weight. Bench HAS to be paused to tech you to maintain tightness
>Superset the bench with a seal row for same sets and reps. Hold an isometric pause of 2 seconds for maximal activation of back. RPE 7-8
>3x10 Some kind of fly. RPE 8-9
I like DB paused floor flies. this is where you get the hypertrophy stimulus for chest, as bench is too low rpe
>12x5 Neutral grip pulldowns, 20 sec rest. Pump training for upper back. RPE 8
>8x8, 30 sec rest. Some kind of curl- ¨
i like using the 8x8, 50% of max old school approach for arms. Progress by adding reps. RPE 8
>10x5, 20 sec rest. Paused db tricep extension, on a decline if possible. Progress by adding reps. RPE 8
>3x10 DB external rotation. start of conservatively on 6% of bench press 1rm. Progress by adding 2 reps

Day 2 Legs (do what you want, but no deadlifting. This is where squats can go)

(1/2)

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.com:
>>69931912
(2/2)


>Day 3 Upper back
3x10 T3 raise (use 5 lbs at most. Hold isometrically at top and lower slowly) 60 sec rest
8x(30% of max pull ups) Neutral grip pullup, 30 sec rest.
4x10 Band pullapart. RPE 8, 45 sec rest
5x5 Chest supported row (Ex seal row), 30 sec rest.
3x10 Hammer Curls. 90 sec rest
3x10 Lying side lateral raise 60 sec rest


>Day 4: Bench accessory day (push)
3x10 Seated shoulder press, can be DB or barbell, rpe 8, 120 sec rest
3x6 Close grip bench, not just regular, but choose either: Board press, pin press, done with bands or chains. RPE 8
3x8 Dips, bw. 60 sec rest. RPE 8
3x10 Kaz press or JM press. RPE 8
3x10 Cable external rotation. RPE 8, 60 sec rest

>Day 5 Legs(Deadlifts go here)+ 1-2 Upper back exercises (inverted row, 1 arm db row, head supported row, pendlay row, whatever)

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.com:
>>69932513
I agree that its mostly chest shoulder tricep size. Lats still help, but i would put most focus on lower traps and rotator cuff. The most common injury while benching is a rotator cuff tear, and if your rotator cuff is weak it will inhibit the cns from activating the prime movers fully. In order to be strong in one direction, you need strength in the antagonist muscles. Think of how you can increase throwing strength by getting stronger in the opposite motion.

OP sounds stupid but actually he's not that wrong.

Scientific studies works with averages. For exemple, let's say a study tells you that 12 reps is optimal for hypertrophy. The study in question have done an average of 100 people, some of which had 15 reps as the optimal and some of which had 8, 12 being the average.

Given you're an individual and not a cohort, your optimal is likely to actually be something other than 12, so you're better of noticing what works with you rather than trying to replicate the optimal for the average person

If you're starting out, I'd personally just take things simple & not worry too much about all the "serious" stuff. Just either get some weights for the start of a home gym or get a gym membership and start working out. After you spend a month or two like that maybe you can start looking into stuff like programs, diets, caloric intake, pre workouts, protein shakes etc. etc.
Just start & see where it takes you and try not to quit, the more you try to do the more likely you'll be to quit.

As a skeleton, I put on 20kg of weight from working out when I couldn't put on fat so while you do need a caloric surplus I don't think you need to bulk before you make muscle & you definitely don't need to cut before you start building muscle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69929958
"definition" is just low bodyfat. Given your stated goal, you should just put the fork down and lose weight, that's it. But realistically, you probably just don't know what you actually need to look the way you want.
Starting Strength is exactly what it says in the name, it starts you off on getting strength. It's a beginner program that will let you get your noob gains quickly. There are others like it. You do it until you stall out (provided you actually ate enough etc) and then do something else depending on your goals - aesthetics, olympic lifts, powerlifting, whatever. It also greatly benefits from smart isolation exercises for muscles that don't get hit much by the main compound lifts.
I think you should just follow a beginner strength program and just do a full bulk/cut cycle once. By the time you're done you will probably have a better understanding of what you want and you will have significantly improved your physique.

>>69930243
Yep, they are periods of time to reach a goal. On your question on what you do between google the phrase "maintenance calories". When you bulk remember to up your intensity in the gym - the whole point of bulking is that you have more fuel to go harder. IF you're on a cut an losing bodyweight rather than fat percentage you likely need to up your training intensity (i.e. how much effort you're expending, not necessarily more sessions or longer sessions), and not prioritising protein.

>>69929958
Starting strength is fine. PPL is also fine. Either is better than no program at all - don't get analysis paralsis by forever comparing programs and never actually sticking to one. Pick one, do it for 3 months. If at the end of the 3 months you don't like it, then change. Don't program hop after a few weeks.

>>69930005
You'll get more effective gains by upping intensity on your training days and actually having proper rest days with some low intensity cardio. Training every day is a classic 'high floor, low ceiling' situation in terms of potential progress. Also, get non-lifting hobbies and schedule all your socialising on rest days to make them fly by.

Is this because really sick or unwell people (from whatever source) are exhausted and will be more likely to die and will also naturally sleep a lot longer because they’re too tired to live… it is it because sleeping longer kills you?

As far as I’ve heard, keep your sleep duration consistent and you’ll get used to it better - no sleeping in some days not others, keep bed time and wake time +/- an hour or less change each day. Try and optimise sleep quality. I’ve had periods where I do 6 hours sleep and it catches up with me after a few months. But I’m also pretty well attuned to when my brain is/is not working optimally. On the other hand 9+ hours seems ok at first but doesn’t really seem to add much benefit, while a regular 7.5 hours seems best overall (plus a minute or so to fall asleep).

So for op idk how to reduce to 6 but I’d say be religious about your sleep/wake times and optimise sleep quality. The other thing is to add some kind of deep rest non-activity at some point in the day to refresh you and your brain/cns.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69931947

That’s not how it works. People’s endurance improves in thin air (like at altitude) because less oxygen causes them to develop a high red blood cell count, which improves oxygen delivery. But working out in thin air conditions actually makes your workout less effective because you’re training your heart itself (which is a muscle) and you’re not able to push it as hard because you’re limited by the low oxygen delivery. The top endurance training programs in the world generally live high up at altitude and will drive down to lower altitudes to work out (the exact opposite of living in normal air then oxygen restricting yourself to work out). Your VO2max likely improved because you were focusing on it and training it consistently, in spite of the mask not because of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69930717
The hair-loss rumor stems from a single study conducted in 2009 in South Africa in which a group of college-aged rugby players took creatine every day for three weeks. The study showed a “statistically significant” increase in the participants’ levels of dihydrotestosterone (DHT), the testosterone byproduct that, in high concentrations, can shrink hair follicles, shorten the hair growth cycle, and cause hair to thin.

However, according to Dr. Antonio—who, along with an internationally renowned team of researchers, reviewed the most common creatine misconceptions for the Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition—none of the rugby players in the study actually experienced hair loss as a result of taking the supplement. What’s more, the people in the study who received the creatine started out with baseline DHT levels 23% lower than the placebo group, and their measured increase in DHT “remained well within normal clinical limits.” In other words, their DHT levels started out low and they stayed low. “‘Statistically significant’ is not the same thing as physiologically meaningful,” Dr. Antonio explains.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69930808
Luckily for you anon I also have an industrial engineering degree so I may have relevant advice for you. I did nothing but Doordash from February to July 2019 because I was apparently unhirable. In May of last year I started a job making $105,000 per year plus a bonus, still less than four years since my graduation in August 2018.

1. Get an internship. It's not too late. I did one the summer I graduated (the only class I had remaining was literature) and I've met several others who also got internships after graduating. Though the pay is less than a permanent job, it's temporary and will help improve whatever permanent job you eventually get.

2. Get a contract position. These are internships but better. I did three in a row paying $25/hr from August 2019 to May 2021. The pay was lower than I wanted, but I became experienced all the same, with three different companies, in three different roles. I learned lots of things, including what I actually wanted to do and what kind of environments I like to work in.

3. Do not be afraid to move. I'm not sure where you live, but there may not be something for you there. I was in a 200,000 urban 1,000,000 metro city and couldn't find anyone to hire me. I moved to Chicago with nothing but my clothes and TV and $300 in the bank and got a job a month later. I'm still here. I don't plan to be here forever, but wherever I do end up, I will be much more qualified than I was, because I moved somewhere with lots of jobs.

4. Don't look for your dream position. My title is now industrial engineer, which I always wanted, but I've also had the titles warehouse manager, distribution analyst (a contract), and production planner (also a contract). I learned in all of these roles even though they weren't my dream role. You'll get money and experience from roles you may not want forever, and you can use those to get the job you really want.

>>69931137
>since i have nothing to add to conversations

Why not, anon? You should be able to talk about simple things, even if you aren't fully invested. Autists struggle with normies 95% of the time because they don't have the willingness to step down their higher thinking functions to communicate about simpler shit with normies.You may be invested in a bunch of deep shit, but know that not everyone may share your understanding of complex topics.

The best advice I can give to you is to familiarize yourself with a wide variety of basic topics, especially ones that have to do with modern news. Learn how to give your opinion on them, and it will seem like you're well-versed in many ground level topics. For example:
>the weather, this one is fucking basic
>sports teams, you should maybe know what accomplishments your local team has made recently
>entertainment news, knowing new albums or current artists is a great starting point
>avoid politics as it can be quite polarizing, but know what powerful people have decided on recently
>know about the outdoors and what you have explored recently, this one can be real easy to learn and cheap at the same time
...And so on. Just step it down a notch and break it down to basics. Try not to jump too hard from topic to topic and just focus on being light and courteous. It goes a long way, trust me. Don't get too deep until you get better at conversation, start with baby steps.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69918620
If you jump into a lot of Z2 "base" training without supporting the miles with Z1 walking and Z0 mobility/stretching you will eventually get injured due to tightness in the body. The body likes to stay balanced. You need to "reset", in a sense, your body after runs, especially long runs, otherwise it gets "molded" into a tighter position it uses during running, which can get too tight if not corrected and cause injury.
It can also just limit your muscular development and speed as a runner. I myself was a victim of this. I did a lot of easy miles, built a massive aerobic base, but it did not translate into higher speeds because of this issue.

posts.com: do i have to bring my phone with me if i want my garmin (fenix 6x) watch to track where i ran? does it have GPS in built or does it require internet (bluetooth to phone)?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69919474
The Garmin Fenix 6X does have built-in GPS, so you don't necessarily need to bring your phone with you while running. The watch can track your location and record your route and other data such as pace, distance, and heart rate.

However, if you want to have access to features like live tracking, music controls, or the ability to receive notifications, you'll need to pair the watch with your smartphone via Bluetooth. In this case, you would need to have your phone with you while running.

In summary, the Fenix 6X has built-in GPS, so you don't need your phone with you to track your runs, but having your phone with you will provide additional features and connectivity options.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69919851
>I've had the same shoes for a while and the padding is basically gone but I don't know if that's the problem.
Could absolutely be the problem. You can get shoes from last season for major discounts, like half off. Do a lil research or head to your local running store and ask for some daily trainers from last season.

Could also be just general weakness. If you have weak calves, your foot will take the brunt of the impact with weak muscles up the chain to help absorb the impact. Check out some calve work outs and do em a few times a week.

>>69931719
BMI is made for average height, more specifically average height from decades ago. It's stacked against tall people.

The BMI goes up with squared height because it's simple. But that's an approximation that loses touch with reality more and more when you get to more extreme heights (in both directions).

Obviously, people aren't 2D, but exist in three dimensions. (Yes, make your hentai joke). People don't get thicker quite as much as they get taller and wider, but it's also not negligible. So the BMI formula should use height^2.4 or something to be more accurate, instead of height ^2.

In effect, tall people with the same overall proportions and bf% have a higher BMI than shorties. Also it obviously doesn't care about fat vs muscles.

This doesn't add to the discussion btw.

Real honest to goodness overtraining takes longer than one to two weeks, recovery time is measured in months.
So many of the bodies systems get crushed, the immune system, hormonal system, energy system, central nervous system.

There has been lots of scientific investigation into the overtraining syndrome over the past century.

Skiing.
“Sport” roller blading (or ice skating if it’s not in the same circle every time).
Rock climbing.
Kayaking/kayak racing; sports in whitewater, or open water. maybe cane also, but you have to switch side symmetrically.
There’s a few for you.

I used to do 10 sets of barbell curls at home, same exercise, been lifting at home for years.

I joined a gym about 6 months ago and I still do 10 sets of curls, but instead of just doing barbell curls, I do dumbbell curls and cable curls. So 4 sets of barbell curls, 3 sets of dumbbell curls, and 3 sets of cable curls.

They say people die twice. Once when they die, and once more when their name is spoken for the very last time. I'd argue the first death a man can go through is when he goes bald.
Your hair is a physical expression of your personality, your youth and your vigor. The idea of looking at one of the very few and exclusive parts of you that is exposed and shown to the world on a daily basis rot away slowly leaving you a shadow of your former self causes my blood pressure to rise in fear. In the eyes of women, bald men are all but invisible. If pressed, they will tell comforting lies about how being bald is not an issue, but they will laugh at bald men behind their back.
>I don't mind your bald head
>It makes you look more manly
>I think it's distinguishing

Your hair follicle is dying due to DHT sensitivity. Fin reduces the amount of DHT on the scalp in turn stopping this process.

Min from what I understand speeds up and lengthens the growth cycle of hairs on the scalp. It doesn't address the root issue and eventually the hair loss will continue.

I think derma rolling encourages the growth of new hair too. It supposedly improves the effects of minoxidil immensely.

Check out HairCafe or Hair Loss Show on YouTube. Both channels provide a lot of info and will give better explanation than me. Kevin is a bit abrasive but I think he's just trying to get people to act before it's too late.

Hope this helps

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69932128
Ok, so your weight is not the problem.
>I’ve made a point to try and fore foot run because I’ve been led to believe that’s the best way?
It is good but not for beginners. If you are starting out run the way it feels most natural to your body.
Take care to keep your legs flexed. If you still feel pain try to strike at the midfoot or at least somewhere between heel and midfoot and shorten your steps.
Even pavement is ok as long as you are not running on concrete blocks but dirt path will be easier on your joints unles the path is uneven, which can seriously fuck you up.
Try to start 30 min. for 5km for a few weeks until you body gets used to running.

I know it's not that fast, but this is more about your body getting used to running. You can speed it up very quickly.
Cardio improves very fast if you stay consistent and it isn't about going all out, so I wouldn't worry about the time you take to run the 5km but your heartrate.
If you have a heartbeat monitor, try to stay below 160 for the whole run.
If you can do that start increasing your speed.

>>69931737
>if endurance is my sole goal, is zone 2 still better? I just get tired way too quickly from daily activities overall.
No, the best would be a mix of zone 2, and zones 3-5. Zone 2 is done because it will let you train more often and recover faster. Zone 3-5 tend to be where you get the fastest results for heart and cardiovascular gains. Pretty much most running routines use a ratio of approximately 2 zone 3-5 workouts a week and 4 zone 2 workouts a week.

You will lose muscle. Muscle basically breaks down when you work out and get rebuilt bigger and stronger with adequate protein intake. posts.com:
>>69928448
>in what way, specifically?
Depression is a symptom but it is not a disorder. If someone is depressed there is always a reason. It could be poor life decisions, it could be trauma, it could be loneliness, it could be stress, it could be dopamine addiction, it could be sleep deprivation, it could be a million things, but there's always a reason. "muh inate chemical imbalance" is bullshit. It is a natural reaction to certain stimuli.
If you're dehydrated, you'll get a headache. You don't take painkillers when you need to drink water. Treating depression with pills is taking painkillers for your headache instead of water. However like depression, there are a million ways to get a headache, but the headache is just a symptom, like depression. Fix the disorder and the symptom goes away.

Humans are incredibly complex creatures and need a very specific balance of comfort, stress, company and solitude. Just because one hasn't diagnosed the cause yet doesn't mean it's not there, there is ALWAYS a reason for the symptom.

>if you feel like shit for no reason thats clinical depression
There is always a reason for the symptom

Your logic is backwards in actual application. the thing with kicks is that they are super strong, but it's way easier to fail
you can lose balance, miss, slip, anything can happen, really. long stretch kicks against an enemy's quads are good, to tire them out, but in real fights you just don't want to gamble at all

stick to be immovable with very strong and stable foot position on ground
keep your distance until the enemy makes a mistake, exploit the mistake with swift strikes from your fist or palm and if the enemy gets close get low, for better leverage, protect yourself from enemy knees and throw them to the ground
most adversaries are clueless once they've been thrown and it gives you time to help allies or subjugate the enemy as a team, once they're on the ground
if it's a 1v1 you shouldn't bother further once the enemy has dropped to the ground
you've won
either escape or stand your ground confidently
depending on the surface a simple throw can bring long term damage to any enemy, as can simple strikes, with enough force
don't forget that protecting yourself is the most important thing in a fight
going down to grapple an enemy after you've thrown them could be their strength, so just avoid it

posts.name: Naraguchi
posts.com:
>>69930758
I might be able to help you bros. I think what it might me is a rotator cuff weakness. This can cause inhibition of activation of the prime movers in bench press = no gains. go to the gym and test your db seated external rotation ( on knees, no cheating, full rom). find your 10rm. If your 10rm is less than 8% of bench 1rm, this can be causing bench weakness. Get your external rotation strength to at least 13% of bench max for 8 reps. Make sure to progressively overload your rotator cuffs, remember, your aiming for strength. Also weakness in scapular stability can also cause bench weakness, so do t3 raises(lower traps). Also lying side lateral raises for supraspinatus. Building these muscles will also make your shoulders a lot healthier.

well yes and no.

At the heart of it, it is CICO. BUT there are things that get in the way. Not all calories are the same. Like you can't eat 2500 calories of protein and expect your mood and body to work like you were on 2500 calories of fat or sugar. Your brain can't run on protein for one thing and your muscles can't replace glycogen with protein. Also if you ate 2500 calories of sugar, you could think and do a workout, but you'd eventually crash and you'd wear yourself down eventually not having protein to repair your muscles. You'd also probably build up an insulen resistance making it harder on your body to burn stored fat. You'd just get tired and go sit because your body doesn't want to give up the fat This would look like your body was burning fewer calories daily.

I don't know why we keep having this discussion. Really, eat at a calorie suplus or just fast if you want to burn fat. Try to keep your diet full of protein, fat and fiber. Don't eat a lot of processed food, especially shit full of white flour and cane sugar. Keep your protein intake at 1 gram of protein per pound of body weight to build and maintain muscle.

I guess Europeans get pissed about this and shit up threads because they love pasta and bread not realizing Americans have to cut this shit because American bread is like a 15 inch long candy bar.

posts.com:
Two packs 16oz ground buffalo.
Two packs 16oz ground turkey, fat percentage to preference.
1 tbsp garlic salt
2 tbsp red pepper flakes
1 tbsp avocado oil
Mix all by hand, pan fry brown, stirring often
Divide evenly into 10 bowls, ~45 grams protein per meal. Pair with veggies/rice/etc. Makes a much leaner, more protein dense hamburger consistency. May potentially help people who have trouble with intake because of this, but ymmv.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69923463
homemade chipotle bowls
>chicken
>taco seasoning or whatever kind of seasoning you want
>pinto beans
>fajita vegetables (bell peppers and onions)
>mushrooms if you want
>rice (I usually just use jasmine rice)
>cilantro
>side of greens for more diverse fiber than the beans
can put it in a wrap or eat it in a bowl
It's easy because all you have to do is roughly cut 2 medium sized onions with 3-4 bell peppers, two cans of pinto beans (make sure to rinse them so you don't eat the bpa), fry chicken thighs in your largest pan, and make a bunch of rice. Once the chicken is done, let it rest, then chop it up and put it back in the bowl with the seasoning. Roughly chop the cilantro and add it to the rice when it's done.
It's delicious and pretty easy.

beef stew with roasted vegetables
>beef (use cheap cut)
>onion
>carrot
>mushrooms
>thyme, lots and lots of thyme
>beef stock (water will do but stock is better)
>for the roasted vegetables:
>cauliflower (trust me it comes out good)
>potato
>carrot
Roughly chop the meat, carrots, onion, and mushrooms. If you want you can quickly brown the meat, but it's not really necessary. add those into a slow cooker or large pot with the beef stock. Just barely cover the ingredients with the stock. Bring to a simmer then turn to a very low simmer. Check periodically to add more stock, but leave it for 5 hours. Obviously season it. For the roasted vegetables: but the potatoes, cauliflower, and carrots into relatively small pieces. It's easy to make wedges out of the cauliflower. As long as the thickness isn't too big it won't matter. Put in large bowl and toss it with olive oil and savory herbs like thyme or herbs de provence. Add salt. Spread out on baking sheets and bake at 400 F until golden.
This is more involved than meal 1 because of the time involved and watching everything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Chili w/beans.
In a large Dutch oven saute 1 chopped onion with minced garlic with your choice of oil/fat (I usually use bacon fat) until soft, then add 2lbs 93% ground beef and brown. Season meat with salt, pepper, cayenne, cumin. Roughly dice 3 poblano peppers and finely dice a few habaneros and add to pot. Add 2 cups beef broth, 1 can each of black beans, kidney beans, diced tomatoes, and a few tablespoons of tomato paste. Bring to boil and let simmer ~1 1/2 hours. Makes about 10 10oz servings with each serving being around 300cal & 30g of protein. Ends up pretty spicy which I like but peppers can be substituted for bell peppers and/or jalapenos. I usually eat half for lunch throughout the week and freeze the other half for later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>2 lbs of sweet potato peeled and sliced
>pressure cooker for 15min
>In a bowl 1 egg 1 tbs butter minced green onions salt pepper
>Throw sweet potato still hot in the bowl and mash

>chicken tender
>remove tendon and skin
>food processor + seasoning
>plastic wrap the chicken hamburger and store it in the freezer
I season it with garlic, salt, pepper and cilantro

>tilapia fillet
>garlic + lemon zest
>fridge
no salt, no acidic ingredients. That way it will keep the moist. Season after cooking (I just use fleur de sel). Always with a hot pan, medium heat and a drop of oil. I aim for around 3min each side.

I also cook pasta in the pressure cooker but there is not much to it. Just water, pasta(semolina) and salt. 1 minute in pressure. Release the pressure(put a kitchen towel over the valve otherwise starch will fly everywhere) and immediately drain it.
